content.text:
Use the vapor pressures of ClF_3 given in the following table to calculate the enthalpy of vaporization using a graphical method or a least squares fitting routine. <image 1>

A. 25.28kJ/mol
B. 20.32 kJ/mol
C. 22.88 kJ/mol
D. 30.58 kJ/mol

To calculate the enthalpy of vaporization (ΔH_vap) using the given vapor pressures (P) and temperatures (T), we can use the Clausius-Clapeyron equation:

\[ \ln(P) = \frac{\Delta H_vap}{R} \left( \frac{1}{T} - \frac{1}{T_0} \right) \]

where:
- \( \ln(P) \) is the natural logarithm of the vapor pressure,
- \( \Delta H_vap \) is the enthalpy of vaporization,
- \( R \) is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol·K),
- \( T \) is the temperature in Kelvin,
- \( T_0 \) is the temperature at which the vapor pressure is 1 Torr.

First, we need to convert the temperatures from Celsius to Kelvin:

\[ T_{Kelvin} = T_{Celsius} + 273.15 \]

Now, we can calculate the enthalpy of vaporization using the given vapor pressures and temperatures:

1. For \( T = -46.97°C \):
\[ \ln(P) = \frac{\Delta H_vap}{8.314} \left( \frac{1}{-46.97} - \frac{1}{-46.97 + 273.15} \right) \]
\[ \ln(P) = \frac{\Delta H_vap}{8.314} \left( \frac{1}{-46.97} - \frac{1}{1200.15} \right) \]
\[ \ln(P) = \frac{\Delta H_vap}{8.314} \left( \frac{1}{-46.97} - \frac{1}{1200.15} \right) \]
\[ \ln(P) = \frac{\Delta H_vap}{8.314} \left( \frac{1}{-46.97} - \frac{1}{1200.15} \right) \]
